The world is coming to south Davis County this weekend.

The Bountiful Davis Art Center is hosting its 50th Summerfest arts celebration, a time for visitors to witness the dances, visual art creations and various crafts from folks from Mexico, Peru, China, India, the Pacific Island region and more.

It is also an opportunity for Utah’s diverse population to create art.

“People forget that we’re all creative. That’s what makes us human,” said Sarina Ehrgott, executive director of the Bountiful Davis Art Center. “And there is enough culture here in the state of Utah that want to bring attention to that.”
• None When: Friday and Saturday, Aug. 8 and 9, 10 a.m. to 8 p.m.
• None Cost: Entrance is free. Cost varies for food from Food League trucks and participation in some workshops.

The art center opened 51 years ago, and shortly thereafter, officials organized Summerfest as a way to learn, celebrate and share the art of different cultures. Folk groups have sung and danced. Hindi dance groups have wowed with their movements. Mexican visual artists have taught families how to create piñatas.

This weekend, guests will see similar activities and performances, but in a different locale than in recent years. Bountiful City Park will host the 2025 Summerfest, the first time since before the COVID-19 pandemic.

On average — at any point during a Summerfest weekend — 150 people could be seen watching performances, taking their children to the Art Yard, an area to create, or maybe eating food from different cultures due to the Food Truck League’s participation in the event.

This year, Ehrgott anticipates 200 people will participate in a Summerfest program at any point in time, but in truth, the art center’s focus is on getting more people connected to art and to different cultures, not on counting how many people are coming in and out of the event.

The event is free to allow everyone the opportunity to come and participate in the art celebration, Ehrgott said. Anyone can sit and watch a dance performance, and children are free to run around the Art Yard.

As Ehrgott, who is the only full-time employee at the center, says art is a human right, and as such it should be accessible to everyone.

Art is also a perfect entryway into learning about different cultures, she said. Art can be what allows someone in Bountiful, who does not have a connection with anyone from a different culture, to ease their way into learning about a new heritage or background.

In other words, everyone — every culture — creates art, as Larry Fitzpatrick, a tech expert, wrote in BBN Times when highlighting tech culture and art.

You do not need to get on a plane to gain access to the human right of artistic expression, as Ehrgott said. This weekend, you can gain access to art right here in Bountiful.

“We want people to know that you can be involved in art in many ways,” Ehrgitt said. “It’s about having a moment to yourself. It’s about the process.”

To see a schedule of Summerfest events and activities, visit www.bdac.org/summerfest.

Summerfest is a cornerstone event that highlights the universal language of art and its ability to connect people across cultures. FREE | Open to everyone.

Art Yard At Summerfest
A Creative Space for All Ages
The Art Yard is a welcoming, hands-on creative area where children, teens, and families can participate in fun, interactive art activities during Summerfest. With adult supervision, participants are invited to explore different artistic techniques and express themselves freely through a variety of workshops, stations, and collaborative projects.
Cyanotype Workshop
With Artist Sara Serratos
Led by photographer, educator, and interdisciplinary artist Sara Serratos, this workshop introduces participants of all ages to the magic of cyanotype printing, a photographic technique known for its striking blue tones. During the session, you'll learn how to coat paper with UV-sensitive chemicals, arrange natural or translucent objects on the surface (like leaves, flowers, or lace), and expose your design to sunlight. After rinsing and drying, you'll be left with a beautiful one-of-a-kind blueprint! Sara will guide participants through the process in both Spanish and English. Materials will be provided, but you’re welcome to bring your own objects to print.
Collective Painting: "World in Peace, Cultures Safe, We Are Stronger"
Join us in creating a large-scale collaborative mural! Kids and teens can express their hopes for a peaceful, united world through painting. The finished canvas will be proudly displayed in our community space after Summerfest. Prompt: What would you like to say to the world? How can we live peacefully and celebrate our beautiful planet together?
Rainbow Bubble Station
Play with color and form by making vibrant bubble art! Using safe food coloring and bubble mixtures, kids can create playful, abstract patterns and enjoy the magic of movement, color, and experimentation.
Architectonic Frets Station
Inspired by architectural patterns from different cultures, this station invites all ages to design and build their own geometric frets using recyclable materials like cardboard and paper. Discover how design connects us across time and place.
A Platform for Artists and Performers
For artists and performers, Summerfest is a platform to share their talents, techniques, and traditions with an enthusiastic audience. Artisans showcase their handmade crafts, each item reflecting cultural stories and meticulous craftsmanship. Musicians, dancers, and other performers transform the festival stage into a dynamic tapestry of sound and movement, presenting cultural narratives in ways that captivate and inspire.
Cultural Workshops
Beyond the festival itself, Summerfest extends its reach through a series of cultural workshops held throughout the summer. These workshops provide residents with opportunities to engage directly with master artists and cultural practitioners, learning traditional techniques and exploring the stories behind various art forms. Whether creating pottery, learning a traditional dance, or delving into global culinary arts, participants gain hands-on experiences that foster a deeper understanding of artistic heritage.
Summerfest bridges our community with the global cultural landscape, celebrating the beauty and diversity of artistic traditions across arts disciplines.
A Feast of Flavors
Summerfest partners with the Food Truck League to bring a curated selection of cultural cuisine to the festival. Attendees can enjoy a diverse array of flavors from around the world, perfectly complementing the artistic and cultural performances on stage. Whether you're savoring a dish inspired by global traditions or discovering a new favorite, the carefully chosen food trucks enhance the festival experience.
As you shop for handmade crafts and take in the vibrant performances, the culinary offerings provide an opportunity to explore another layer of culture, making Summerfest a true feast for the senses.
Art Yard at Summerfest
The Art Yard at Summerfest invites young attendees to dive into the world of creativity with project-based activities inspired by the diverse cultures showcased at the festival. Through engaging, hands-on art projects, children can learn about global traditions while expressing their creativity. This interactive space offers a meaningful and fun way for families to connect with the rich cultural heritage celebrated throughout Summerfest.
Building Cultural Bridges
Summerfest enriches the lives of residents by exposing them to diverse artistic practices and cultural traditions from around the world. The festival creates an atmosphere of unity and understanding, offering attendees the chance to experience the richness of global cultures firsthand. At the same time, it provides artists and performers with a space to connect with new audiences, fostering appreciation and exchange.

argos_summary: The Bountiful Davis Art Center is hosting its 50th Summerfest arts celebration on August 8 and 9, featuring performances, workshops, and cultural activities from various global traditions. The event, which is free to the public, aims to connect Utah's diverse population through art and cultural expression, emphasizing that art is a human right accessible to all. Attendees can enjoy performances, participate in hands-on workshops, and explore the Art Yard, all while experiencing a variety of international cuisines from food trucks.
